abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the A
            Kampala Institutional and Infrastructure Development
            Adaptable Program Loan (APL) Project for Uganda was judged
            to be moderately satisfactory. The Bank and borrower
            performance were moderately satisfactory. The risk to
            development outcome was moderate. Significant changes
            included changes to subcomponents in response to practical
            constraints that emerged - mainly implementation delays and
            escalating project costs and two restructurings. Several
            lessons were learned. Instead of re-inventing the wheel, the
            Kampala Institutional and Infrastructure Development Project
            adopted, complemented and strengthened the
            organization's strategy and the Strategic Framework for
            Reform (SFR) and filled in the resource gap where needed.
            This was essential to the sustainability of the
            institutional objectives as it ensured ownership, was not
            disruptive, avoided duplication, and increased efficiency in
            resource usage and implementation. Lessons can be drawn from
            the improvements made by Kampala City Council (KCC)/The
            Kampala Capital City Authority (KCCA) in its institutional
            efficiency and governance. Firstly, there is a strong
            continuity in the reform direction despite the transit of
            KCC to KCCA. The new entity did not abandon the original
            SFR, rather built upon it. Secondly, the SFR was
            comprehensive and adopted a multi-pronged approach, covering
            a range of areas from institution policy formulation and
            performance; political support, management and teamwork;
            organizational reform; management systems; communication and
            corporate image building; financial recovery; and physical
            planning and public health. Implementing agencies should
            enforce more stringent standards when conducting due
            diligence before contract award so as to avoid awarding
            contracts to firms which do not have the requisite technical
            staff, equipment and financial resources. Civil works
            contracts should be packaged in such a way that they provide
            sufficient incentives to attract competent firms with the
            necessary capacity and resources to deliver on the
            assignment. It is crucial for the implementing agency to
            check on the performance of both the contractor and
            supervising consultants directly and frequently. Ensuring
            that there is sufficient human and financial capacity
            requires upfront planning and preparation.
